fullText: The Broadway transfer of this London hit about a boy and his beloved horse during World War I is a theatrical experience that transcends drama to become something closer to a spiritual event.
dtliExcerpt: The Broadway transfer of this London hit about a boy and his beloved horse during World War I is a theatrical experience that transcends drama to become something closer to a spiritual event.
bwwExcerpt: The simple story, which, for all its ferocity, is not so much an anti-war play as a play about the false and brutal lessons that boys learn from their fathers (and the father figures who govern them), and must unlearn at their own peril. But the telling of this age-old tale is pure theatrical magic in this story-theater-like production staged for an all-American company by Marianne Elliott (an associate director of the National) and Tom Morris (a.d. of Bristol Old Vic) and given its heart by the magnificent horsemanship of Adrian Kohler and Basil Jones, creative masterminds of the Handspring Puppet Company.
showScoreExcerpt: The Broadway transfer of this London hit about a boy and his beloved horse during World War I is a theatrical experience that transcends drama to become something closer to a spiritual event.
